Award.AwardTitle: Towards a Resilient Electric Power Grid: An Investment Prioritization Decision Framework Integrating Risks of Severe Weather-Induced Outages

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Severe weather-induced outages in the US electric power system result in devastating, multi-billion dollar damages affecting hundreds of millions of people each year. However, current risk and reliability metrics and standards for both electricity transmission and distribution networks undervalue the impact of extreme events on electric power service, and thus on broader economic and societal costs. In the light of addressing this gap, this research intends to develop new risk assessment methods to deal with the complexities associated with linking outage to societal costs under the uncertainty of weather-related extreme events. This work is expected to inform regulatory decision-making processes for more effectively managing risks and overall security of the electric power system, and to provide a framework for achieving similar innovations in other utility sectors.

This work is expected to result in (1) novel algorithm-based probabilistic risk analysis models for estimating risk of major power outages under severe weather events; (2) advanced economic models to estimate the compounding economic losses due to failure of interdependent infrastructure due to such power outages; and (3) optimization techniques to determine best strategies for addressing deep uncertainties. The research outcomes will be disseminated through peer-reviewed journal publications, with continued engagement of graduate and undergraduate students through coursework and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project led to the development of interdisciplinary tools and techniques for modeling the impacts of natural hazards on critical infrastructure, using publicly accessible databases. The insights and data generated by the project can inform preparations for the potential impact of severe weather events and response decisions by electric utilities as well as energy systems planners. This will also help guide their resilience investment strategies for more robust and equitable outcomes.

The project was conducted in three phases. Phase I of the project performed rigorous predictive analytics, using DOE-collected US-wide electricity service disruption database, to identify key predictors of severe weather- and climate-induced power outages. A database of state-level power outage data together with socioeconomic and climatic information has been developed that can be used to identify and analyze the historical trends and patterns of the major outages and identify and assess the risk predictors associated with sustained power outages in the continental U.S. The researchers also developed a multi-dimensional framework to simultaneously characterize the multi-dimensional measures of infrastructure inoperability, accounting for damaged assets, restoration lengths as well as number and types of affected customers, during extreme events to incentivize more robust and equitable resilience investment decisions. The team also developed a graph theoretic approach to conduct causal inferencing of climate-induced outages cascading through interdependent infrastructure networks.

The phase II of the research has assessed the economic impacts of the severe weather induced power outages in terms of the loss of Gross Domestic Product (GDP). Economic impact assessment of weather-related power outages in terms of loss of GDP is a paradigm shift from the conventional approach. The project has also established the relationships between the 71 constituting industries of the U.S. economy as identified by the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis. The outcomes can be used to identify the industries that are most vulnerable to severe weather induced power outages. The inter-industry relationships identified in this research can also be used in assessing the cascading economic impacts of inoperability of an industry on other sectors. As a part of the project, the research team has proposed a state level multiplier. This multiplier can be derived for all the states in the U.S. and can be used to perform the economic impact assessment in terms of loss of GDP at the state level.

The phase III of the project integrates the outcomes of phase I and II to identify the optimal risk reduction strategies that could minimize the economic impacts of the severe weather induced power outages. A benefit cost analysis-based optimization framework has been developed that finds the optimal scope of different strategies that could maximize the benefits of the identified strategies. Additionally, the framework incorporates the risk appetite of the decision makers by providing five levels of flexibility. The risk appetite helps establish the scope of the resilience building projects and the associated budget. It is expected that the framework can be used by the Investor Owned Utilities (IOUs) for rate approvals from the state utility regulatory commissions by justifying the importance of proposed resilience building projects to the state?s economy.

The outcomes of the project have been presented in Graduate Seminar Series as well as in a graduate-level course on energy systems planning at Purdue University. The funding of the project was used to train two female postdocs and 5 graduate students in civil engineering and industrial engineering including two female Ph.D. students. The two postdocs currently hold faculty positions at The State University of New York (SUNY) and Oklahoma State University (OSU). A graduate student employed in this project was recently awarded a graduate scholarship from the School of Civil Engineering at Purdue University in response to his work in this project. Part of the project results were presented in a poster competition organized by Sigma Xi Scientific Research Society at Purdue University. The poster was awarded the first place. Results have been presented at the International Society for Risk Analysis, INFORMS and IISE as well as departmental seminars at the University at Buffalo, Columbia University and UT Austin.
